oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Charlie Walker Interview About 1952 Material
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of an interview of Charlie Walker (musician) discussing his 1952 material such as "I'm Looking For You", "Stolen Kisses", "Two Red Lips", and "By Rights You Belong To Me", and "Tell Her Lies And Feed Her Candy" This is side 1 of 2.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Charlie Walker
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) -- Discusses a club where Hank Williams, Jimmy Davis, Tex Ritter, Floyd Tillman, Carl Smith, Webb Pierce, Ray Price, Hank Thompson, Bob Wills played in south Texas. (1:34) -- Discusses "In The Jailhouse Now", speaking to RCA about getting Jimmie Rodgers on the jukeboxes. Idea was then sent to Stephen Sholes of RCA. (4:16) -- Discussion about his wife and marrying in 1948. Married for 17 years. (7:35) -- Discusses sessions at KMAC studios. (8:18) -- Begins discussing 1952 material. "I'm Looking For Another You", "Stolen Kisses", "Flaming Jewels", "Two Red Lips", "By Rights You Belong To Me", "Out Of My Arms", "Flock Of My Memories", "I've Never Been To Texas But I've Seen Everything", "Stay Away From My Heart". Discussed personnel: Charlie Walker - Guitar & Vocals, Smiley Whitley - Steel, Jesse Smitty Highsmith - Piano, Jack Jackson - Piano, Interviewer quoted "unknown bass player". Mentions that Fred Rose used to go by "Floyd Jenkins". (10:45) -- Discusses "Arklatex" (11:45) -- Discussion about "Flaming Jewels" (13:55) -- "By Rights You Belong To Me" "Out Of My Arms" Charlie Walker mentions that they are "just love songs." (14:41) -- "I've Never Been Out Of Texas But I've Seen Everything" Charlie Walker wrote it with a "gal who played piano in my band". (15:32) -- "Stay Away From My Heart" Charlie Walker wrote this in his motel room alone. (16:41) Charlie Walker mentions Spud Goodall, a fantastic guitar player who played with Willie Nelson and Tex Ritter. (18:50) Mentions playing with Milton Brown's brother Derwood Brown in Dallas and Ft. Worth area clubs. (19:18) -- Charlie discusses his move from Imperial to Decca. Charlie mentions Ernest Tubb pitching him to Paul Cohen about signing to Decca. "Decca was it, in those days. It was.. RCA, Decca, and Columbia." (20:44) -- 2-01-1954 First session at Castle Studio. "Tell Her Lies And Feed Her Candy" was the first record they made at that session. (22:20) -- "Tell Her Lies And Feed Her Candy" discussion, song was written by Joe McCracken - a pen name for Leon Payne. (26:20) -- Discusses how "Tell Her Lies And Feed Her Candy" was played on Moscow radio as a pitch against The United States. (28:56) -- Discusses long-time friendship and songwriting relationship with Cindy Walker.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Walker, Charlie, 1926-2008;
